content.description:
An experiment was performed to investigate the reaction between <math alttext="Z n" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> metal and <math alttext="N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>i</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at different concentrations. Because the <math alttext="N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>i</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ion is green, the extent of the reaction was determined using spectrophotometric analysis. Four <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> standard solutions of <math alttext="N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>i</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> were prepared by dissolving <math alttext="N i C l 2 with 6 H2O of hydration" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mtext>l</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⋅</mo><mn>6</mn><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> (molar mass <math alttext="240 grams per mole" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>240</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/</mtext><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) in water. The absorbance of each solution was measured; the results are shown both in the table below and in the following plot of the absorbance data.

Solution
 <math alttext="the molar concentration of N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>i</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Absorbance

<math alttext="1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.020" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.020</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.12" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.040" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.040</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.25" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.060" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.060</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.39" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.39</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="4" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.080" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.080</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.question: Which of the following equations best represents the reacting species in the reaction between <math alttext="Z n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> metal and <math alttext="N i C l 2, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="Z n, solid, plus N i C l 2, aqueous, react to produce Z n with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus N i, solid, plus 2 C l with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Zn</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>NiCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo><msup><mi>Zn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>Ni</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>Cl</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

<math alttext="Z n, solid, plus N i C l 2, aqueous, react to produce Z n C l 2, aqueous, plus N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mtext>l</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mtext>l</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mtext>i</mtext><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>

<math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus N i, solid, react to produce Z n, solid, plus N i positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>n</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>i</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="Z n, solid, plus N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, react to produce Z n with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus N i, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>i</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Z</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>n</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="Z n, solid, plus N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, react to produce Z n with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus N i, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>i</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Z</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>n</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 5.E: Determine a balanced chemical equation for a given chemical phenomenon.
